title: What does "FAILURE TO FILE REQUEST FOR ENTRY OF DEFAULT JUDGMENT" mean if I was never served and court records show no service?
question: I am truly perplexed & furious. I just received 3rd party mail from an agency seeking to help people who have collection court cases and there forth found out I was being sued. I find out it is a collections case from a company I have never done business with for credit card debt. Case Summary says this: ( This is edited because no room to post all of it) Thx.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Filing a lawsuit,Civil rights,Summons and complaint,Sued for debt,Default judgment,Civil court
answers:
The "third party" who notified you is probably not licensed to practice law. They either charge you to prepare pleadings for you "in pro per" or try to get you to file bankruptcy.

What you need to do is to consult an attorney. You need to take action right away, or you may lose important legal rights, such as the right to defend the lawsuit on the merits. In your situation there may be a basis for having the debt collector pay your attorney's fees, but an attorney will need to review everything thoroughly before undertaking to represent you on that basis.

I suggest you visit the courthouse where the case was filed and obtain from the civil clerk copies of all the documents filed in the case. Then consult with a debt collections defense attorney regarding your options.

The good news is it appears from the docket that the plaintiff failed you serve you (or the defendant with your name) a copy of the summons and complaint within the 180-day deadline, and due to this failure, the court is about to dismiss the lawsuit. For a better understanding of the court process, read California Rules of Court rule 3.740: http://www.courts.ca.gov/cms/rules/index.cfm?title=three&linkid=rule3_740.
